I have been thinking about this a bit more and I think I understand the problem, which might not be a problem after all. 
Let's say, as in the example above, that we have a firing rate of 1000Hz. With a dt=1, a Poisson process will produce on average 1 spike for each dt. However, it will sometime produce more, and sometime less. However, for each dt we only want to know whether there was a spike or not, thus capping the number of spikes at 1 for each dt. This will consistently under-estimate the number of spikes. 
(the `encoding.poisson` seems to produce spikes in a slightly different way, but I think the result is the same and the problem is still there).

If this hypothesis is correct, then I would expect even less spikes when dt is higher (since theoretically we would produce N spikes for each dt, but we are still capping it at 1). Indeed :
`poisson(torch.tensor(1000, dtype=torch.float32), time=1000, dt=10).sum()` -> ~100 spikes
(instead of ~1000).

The important thing is that this is almost a non problem for more realistic Hz values (that is, much lower, ~1Hz), since it's much less likely that we'll get more than a spike in each single dt. Therefore, maybe, this works as intended and not cause for concern at all. Any idea? Thanks

```
l = list()
for i in range(10000):
   l.append(poisson(torch.tensor(500, dtype=torch.float32), time=1000, dt=1).sum())

a,b = np.histogram(l, bins=5)
print(a)
print(b)
print(f'Min {min(l)} Max {max(l)}')
```
Output:
```
[ 150 2040 5223 2369  218]
[423.  440.8 458.6 476.4 494.2 512. ]
Min 423 Max 512
```

However higher then 600Hz the output seems experience the issue you describe. 

Not sure if this is realistic firing rate, but that is not the expected behavioral.


Note that:
> ``poisson(torch.tensor(1000, dtype=torch.float32), time=1000, dt=10).sum()``-> ~100 spikes

That is the expected behavioral, since the output of the function is 100 array size (1000/10), and and input rate of 1000Hz when express in only in 100 iteration cant be 1000 spikes... 

Anyhow, I will take a look into it later on.

Thanks. Note that even with 500Hz like in the example above, the Poisson under produces spikes:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17203078/210621857-57cbdef6-d60e-4dc0-a850-f90257a41c1e.png)
IIRC the realistic spike frequency for a neuron is estimated to be 1Hz _or much less_.  

I have also found another weird behaviour. Let's now work with a "low" Hz value:
`poisson(torch.tensor(50, dtype=torch.float32), time=1000, dt=1).sum()` 
this is correctly ~50.

Here is an alternative way that _should_ produce the same result:

```
import numpy as np
l = []
for i in range(1000): 
    l.append(poisson(torch.tensor(50, dtype=torch.float32), time=1, dt=1).item())
np.sum(l) => 0
```

surprisingly, this doesn't work!
Even more surprisingly, this starts to work only when Hz > 400! Then the spike sum jumps from 0 to approximately the right value.

The approach above is useful when one wants to do frequent updates, e.g. for RL. 

I'll try to investigate this myself, seems pretty fundamental.

Thank you for investigating this issue. 

One small comment, its doesn't make sense to have the `rate` parameter bigger the `time` parameter.  You cant have rate of 50 ISI in the time spent of `time=1` time-frame and `dt=1`

Hi Hananel, I don't think that's correct. 
As far as I understand, the Poisson distribution describes the probability that a spike falls within a certain dt for a given rate. This is exactly the definition given here: https://www.cns.nyu.edu/~david/handouts/poisson.pdf  (equation 3)

With a 50 hz and time=dt=1 we just have a *very* low chance to get a spike within that dt (and thus within time). The total time (that is, how many "dt" we consider) does not affect the probability for each dt.  So most of the time `poisson(torch.tensor(50, dtype=torch.float32), time=1, dt=1)` should give 0, but sometime it should give 1, and with 1000 times should give 1 around 50 times. 

If the Poisson distribution in this case has a different meaning please let me know!  I do see that it's implemented quite differently that what I said above.

Yes, you are right, that is correct.

l.sum()

Hi Hananel, What about just using something like this? ``` def poisson2(datum, time, dt, clip=True): dist = torch.distributions.Poisson(rate=datum * dt / 1000, validate_args=False) intervals = dist.sample(sample_shape=torch.Size([time//dt])) if clip: intervals = torch.clip(intervals, max=1) return intervals ``` This produces slightly different distributions than the method in `encoding.poisson`. I do believe my method is the correct one, but I am not sure mostly because I do not understand what does `encoding.poisson` do. Note that when `clip=True`, we are automatically enforcing a maximum of one spike per dt (as in `encoding.poisson`. Like the original function, this will under-produce spikes consistently, but I think it's required for the rest of bindsnet to work. However, the user might disable it. We can also disable it to check that the result are theoretically valid when no clipping is applied. Some comparisons: 100Hz ``` plt.hist([poisson2(100, 1000, dt=1, clip=False).sum().item() for _ in range(2000)], bins=50, alpha=0.5, label='poisson2 no clip') plt.hist([poisson2(100, 1000, dt=1, clip=True).sum().item() for _ in range(2000)], bins=50, alpha=0.5, label='poisson2 w clip') plt.hist([poisson(torch.tensor([100]), 1000, dt=1).sum().item() for _ in range(2000)], bins=50, alpha=0.5, label='poisson') ``` Notice how the mean is the same, but the variance is different. 600Hz ``` plt.hist([poisson2(600, 1000, dt=1, clip=False).sum().item() for _ in range(2000)], bins=50, alpha=0.5, label='poisson2') plt.hist([poisson(torch.tensor([600]), 1000, dt=1).sum().item() for _ in range(2000)], bins=50, alpha=0.5, label='poisson') ``` Notice how when not clipping the mean is precisely 600. With clipping, the values are under-estimated, but differently (more!) than `encoding.poisson`. I want to underlie that this under-estimation is now expected and can potentially be disabled by setting clip=False. Again, when Hz is low, it doesn't matter much. 10Hz ``` plt.hist([poisson2(10, 1000, dt=1, clip=False).sum().item() for _ in range(2000)], bins=50, alpha=0.5, label='poisson2') plt.hist([poisson(torch.tensor([10.]), 1000, dt=1).sum().item() for _ in range(2000)], bins=50, alpha=0.5, label='poisson') ``` Notice how peaky is the distribution obtained with `encoding.poisson`. This doesn't look right to me. It means that in a second, with a 10Hz, you will get always either 9 or 10 spikes. 50Hz, but with time=1 repeated 1000 times. This version didn't work at all with `econding.poisson`. Now, with `poisson2`, this works: ``` l = [] for _ in range(1000): l.append(poisson2(50, 1, dt=1).item()) print(np.sum(l)) => ~50 (correct!) l = [] for _ in range(1000): l.append(poisson(torch.tensor([50.]), 1, dt=1).item()) print(np.sum(l)) => 0 (incorrect) ``` I am not claiming that `poisson2` is a `fixed` version of `encoding.poisson`. They really compute something different. Is anyone knows what does `encoding.poisson` do let me know! :)
Wonderful work @ValerioB88, please make a PR with Poisson2 and I will test it later on.

Hi, did we get a this fixed yet? 

I use Poisson encoding in my network and always suspected it didn't produce enough spikes. This is a somewhat important issue in BindsNEet.

Hi @rafaelblevin821 
I didn't have time to work on this. However, you could potentially just copy and paste my `poisson2` function in your code and use it directly. That's used only for the input spikes anyway. 

I want to stress how my solution produces a more theoretically correct Poisson distribution - however, used in conjunction with the rest of BindsNET *it will still under-produce spikes*: if you set `clip=False` it will NOT under-produce spikes; however, in this case, I am almost sure the rest of the code will break (so you should always use the default `clip=True` when `poisson2` is used in conjunction with BindsNet. 

This is why:
`poisson2` returns the number of spikes for each dt. Let's say you use 10Hz, so a fairly low spiking rate. Most of the time each dt will have a spike of 0, sometime a spike of 1 and rarely a spike >1, e.g. let's say you end up with a spiking vector of `[0, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0, 0, 2, 0]`.  However, the spiking vector is supposed to be a binary vector, and the behaviour for values >1 is undefined. That's why we should always clip values at maximum 1 spikes per dt (which would just return `[0, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0, 0, 1, 0]`. And that's why you will always have under-production of spikes, and why the problem becomes more noticeable for high spiking rates (that is: it's more likely that a dt will contain more than 1 spike). I don't think there is an obvious way to solve this. 

I hope that's clear.
